items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Consideration of Petition for Proposed Summit Public Schools - Charter School Rainier
	 
	 
On June 25, 2010, the District received a charter petition from Summit Public Schools, a non-profit corporation organized to provide education programs and services and to manage, operate, guide, direct and promote one or more California public charter schools.  The Petition from Summit Public Schools proposes to establish Summit Public School: Rainier in the East Side Union High School District Community serving students in 9th through 12th grades.  The Petition proposes to begin with 9th grade in fall of 2011-12 and add a grade level each year until it serves all grades 9th through 12th in August / September 2014.
	 
The District held a public hearing on the Petition as required by law during the public session of the Board Meeting on August 19, 2010.
	 
At the public hearing, Diane Tavenner, Founder and CEO of Summit Public Schools, presented information about the proposed charters Rainier and Tahoma.  In addition several parents who reside in the East Side Union High School District addressed the Board to express their interest in sending their children to the proposed charter school.  No District teachers or other District employees addressed the Board at the hearing, or have otherwise expressed support for the proposed school.
	 
The District must now either grant or deny the charter petition.  The District may grant the charter “if it is satisfied that granting the charter is consistent with sound educational practice.”  The District may not deny a petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support or more of the following findings:
	 
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for pupils to be enrolled in the charter school;
The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition;
The petition does not contain the required number of signatures;
The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the required conditions set forth in section 47605(d); or
The petition does not contain reasonable comprehensive descriptions of the 15 elements of a charter school set forth in Education Code Section 47605(b)
	 
If the Board makes one or more of these five findings, it must also adopt written factual findings that are specific to the issues raised in this particular Petition.
	 
The District’s administration team carefully reviewed and analyzed the Petition, and met with representatives from Summit Public Schools in order to discuss their petition.  As set forth in the attached Proposed Findings, Administration recommends that the Summit Public Schools – Rainier Charter Petition be granted, subject to the following conditions being met: (1) the parties will enter into a mutually agreeable Memorandum of Understanding implementing, as necessary, the approved provisions of the Petition; (2) Article IV (“Governance Structure”) of the Petition shall be revised to reflect that the ESUHSD Governing Board shall be entitled to a representative on the Board of Directors of Summit Public Schools in accordance with Education Code section 47604(b); (3) The Petition will be amended to specify whether the members of the Board of Directors are compensated and, if so, identify the types and amount of compensation and indicate where in the budget (Petition, Exhibit “R”, Operating Budget) such compensation is reflected; (4) to ensure parent and community participation, the Petition and Appendix I thereto will be modified to clarify that all meetings of the Board of Directors of Summit Public Schools shall be held within the territorial jurisdiction of the East Side Union High School District; (5) ESUHSD does not agree to the “Dispute Resolution” provisions contained at pp. 55-57 of the Petition insofar as such terms are different than, in addition to, or a limitation on or alteration of the ESUHSD’s rights and oversight responsibilities under the Education Code; (6) the Petition shall be modified to reflect whether or not Summit Public Schools will impose a fee or charge on its students for after-school and extra-curricular activities and programs.
	 
In addition, administration strongly recommends and encourages Summit Public Schools to modify the “Public Random Drawing and Preferences” on pp. 59-60 of the Petition to grant first and second priority preferences for admission to District residents including: (i) siblings of currently enrolled students or graduates of SPS: Rainier residing within the boundaries of the District, and (ii) students residing within the boundaries of the District.
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
General Fund
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
If approved there will be fiscal impact.  The anticipated fiscal impact is not subject to quantification at this time due to the varying uncertainties with state funding, actual charter operations and the extent to which the charter school draws upon non-reimbursable District services.
	 
	 
	 
 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees give careful consideration to this Petition and the concerns raised by the Administration.  If the Boards acts to deny the Petition, the Board should adopt the attached Findings as support for the Board’s decision.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Consideration of Petition for Proposed Summit Public Schools - Charter School Tahoma
	 
	 
On June 25, 2010, the District received a charter petition from Summit Public Schools, a non-profit corporation organized to provide education programs and services and to manage, operate, guide, direct and promote one or more California public charter schools.  The Petition from Summit Public Schools proposes to establish Summit Public School: Tahoma in the East Side Union High School District Community serving students in 9th through 12th grades.  The Petition proposes to begin with 9th grade in fall of 2011-12 and add a grade level each year until it serves all grades 9th through 12th in August / September 2014.
	 
The District held a public hearing on the Petition as required by law during the public session of the Board Meeting on August 19, 2010.
	 
At the public hearing, Diane Tavenner, Founder and CEO of Summit Public Schools, presented information about the proposed charters Rainier and Tahoma.  In addition several parents who reside in the East Side Union High School District addressed the Board to express their interest in sending their children to the proposed charter school.  No District teachers or other District employees addressed the Board at the hearing, or have otherwise expressed support for the proposed school.
	 
The District must now either grant or deny the charter petition.  The District may grant the charter if it complies with the law and “if it is satisfied that granting the charter is consistent with sound educational practice.”  The District may not deny a valid petition for the establishment of a charter school unless it makes written factual findings, specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support or more of the following findings:
	 
The charter school presents an unsound educational program for pupils to be enrolled in the charter school;
 The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition;
The petition does not contain the required number of signatures;
The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the required conditions set forth in section 47605(d); or
The petition does not contain reasonable comprehensive descriptions of the 15 elements of a charter school set forth in Education Code Section 47605(b)
	 
If the Board makes one or more of these five findings, it must also adopt written factual findings that are specific to the issues raised in this particular Petition.
	 
The District’s administration team carefully reviewed and analyzed the Petition, and met with representatives from Summit Public School in order to discuss their petition.  The Petition has also been reviewed by the District’s Legal Counsel because the Petition, which is virtually identical to the Summit Public Schools: Rainier charter school petition, raises significant legal issues as to whether or not the Education Code allows Summit Public Schools to submit two identical charter petitions for two separate but identical charter schools under these circumstances.  The Administration and Legal Counsel continue to address these legal issues with Summit Public Schools and its counsel.  In light of these considerations, and as set forth in the attached Proposed Findings but subject to on-going discussions between the District and Summit Public schools and its legal counsel, Administration recommends that the Summit Public Schools Charter petition for Tahoma be denied.
	 
If denied by the Board, the Board is required to adopt findings in support of its denial.
If the Board determines to approve the Petition, then Administration recommends that approval be subject to the same conditions as set forth with regard to the Board’s approval of the Summit Public Schools: Rainier charter petition.
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
General Fund
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
If approved there will be fiscal impact.  The anticipated fiscal impact is not subject to quantification at this time due to the varying uncertainties with state funding, actual charter operations and the extent to which the charter school draws upon non-reimbursable District services.
	 
	 
	 
 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees give careful consideration to this Petition and the concerns raised by the Administration.  If the Boards acts to deny the Petition, the Board should adopt the findings as support for the Board’s decision.

SUBJECT:
Excuse Absence of Board President Eddie Garcia from the September 16, 2010, Board Meetings (Education Code Section 35120)
	 
	 
The District has been informed that Board President Eddie Garcia is ill, he requires medical care, and will be absent from the September 16, 2010, Board meeting due to his illness. 
	 
Per Education Code section 35120(c), a Board Member who is absent from a meeting may receive his/her monthly stipend if the Board adopts a resolution finding that the Board member was absent due to illness.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$675 Board Monthly Stipend
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board resolve and find that Board President Eddie Garcia's absence was due to his illness and that the Board excuse his absence from the September 16, 2010, Board Meeting.

SUBJECT:
California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nominations for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic. The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting at the San Francisco Marriott Marquis Hotel on December 1-2, 2010. Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a Board Member from a CSBA member district or county office of education. Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference. 
	 
The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommend that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: Asian/Pacific Islander and Hispanic.

Item:  10.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m. on Resolution #2010/2011-07 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
	 
BACKGROUND
Education Code Section 60119 requires that local Board of Education hold a public hearing and declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks and standards.  If the Governing Board finds an insufficiency, it must make known to the public the reasons for the insufficiency and take action to ensure that the situation is remedied within eight weeks from the start of school.  This public hearing is intended to comply with the regulation.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	To be determined
	 
 
FUNDING SOURCE
 
	Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
	State Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION
	The administration recommends that the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2010/2011-07 and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 26, 2010 as required by the Education Code Section 60119.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  10.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students - Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Indviduals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommendated waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
Student A
Student B
Student C
Student D
Student E
Student F
Student G
Student H
Student I
Student J
Student K
Student L
Student M
Student N
Student O
Student P
Student Q
				 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent,
                                    Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Approve Provisional Internship Permit Requests for Certificated Employees
	 
	 
Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.
	 
The Provisional Internship Permit (PIP) was created in response to the phasing out of emergency permits and became effective on July 1, 2006.  It allows an employing agency to hire an individual who has not yet met the subject matter competence requirement needed to enter an internship program.
	 
The district is requesting approval of the following provisional internship permit requests for the 
2010-2011 school year.
	 
Provisional Internship Permit
	 
 CORTEZ, Miguel
 Physical Education
 Yerba Buena
 GALLEGOS, Vicky
 Special Education
 W. C. Overfelt
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the provisional internship permit requests.

Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Public Hearing Notice at Approximately 6:30 p.m. regarding Resolution #2010/2011-08 Gann Spending Limit
	 
	 
In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2010/2011-08 Gann Spending Limit.
	 
The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the Amendment must calculate their Appropriations Limit for the coming year.  There is no direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the Gann Limitation and other 2010/2011 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with proceeds of taxes.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-09 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2010 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount of not to Exceed $75,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District
	 
This resolution authorizes the District to sell and issue Bonds in the amount not to exceed of $75,000,000 for the General Obligation Bonds 2002 Election, Series B and 2003 Refunding General Obligation Bonds, Series A, and 1999 Election Series C.  The reason for doing this is for a cost savings to tax payers for the retirement of that original debt (cost of paying off the bonds).  The Municipal Bond Market is currently at a level that interest cost for bond earnings is less than interest on the bonds issued for those previous bond sales.  It is estimated that this could be a savings of 5% over the life of the Bonds.  Generally it is worth the effort of going through a sale and issuance of refunding bonds if the agency can realize a 3% savings.  This will not provide any additional funds to the District but will have the impact of reducing the taxes for our District Tax Payers by approximately $2,000,000. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2010/2011-09 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2010 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount of not to Exceed $75,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
Item:  13.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-10 Authorizing Filing Application for Qualified School Construction Bond Allocation and Approving Related Actions
	 
Qualified School Construction Bonds (“QSCBs”) were created under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (“ARRA” or “Stimulus Bill”).  QSCBs are an interest subsidized financing vehicle for the construction, acquisition, rehabilitation or repair of K-12 school facilities.  QSCBs provide either federal tax credits to bondholders or reimbursement of interest costs to school districts in order to reduce the cost of borrowing. The intent of this program is to meet the ARRA goals of stimulating the economy and generating jobs.
	 
Regulations regarding the 2010 QSCB program have been passed by the State Legislature and await the Governor’s signature for enactment.  Applications may be submitted to the California Department of Education 30 business days after enactment.  As with the 2009 QSCB program, applications will be limited to $25 million per district.  However, unlike last year’s program, only those districts able to repay the QSCBs with available GO bond authority will be permitted to apply (with certain minor exceptions).  Selection among applicants will be made on the following basis: a) date of receipt of application (by certified mail);  b) projects having Department of State Architect approval and; c) the greater percentage of a district’s pupils who qualify for the federal free and reduced priced meals program and are enrolled in the program. 
	 
Should the District receive a QSCB allocation, this program may allow for the acceleration of the District’s proposed projects.  While the prospect of low interest financing is attractive, the amount borrowed under the QSCB program must still be repaid within a 13 to 17-year timeframe.  As such, the District’s financial advisor, Dale Scott & Company, will work with staff to develop a financing program that serves the best interests of the District and its taxpayers.  
	 
The apparent benefits of the QSCB program suggest it would be advantageous to submit an allocation application.  The attached resolution is designed to accompany the application to the State.  If, after applying and receiving an allocation, the District decides not to use all or a part of the allocation for whatever reason, it can be returned without penalty to the State.   Any subsequent financings that take place due to receipt of a QSCB allocation by the District will be brought to the Board for approval.  All professional fees and expenses associated with the QSCB application process and subsequent transactions are wholly contingent on the successful completion of the necessary financings and will not be paid out of the District’s general fund.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Appllicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2010/2011-10 Authorizing Filing Application for Qualified School Construction Bond Allocation and Approving Related Actions.

SUBJECT:
Approve the Authorization for the District to Utilize Third Party Pay Processes with Bank of America, E-Pay and the American Express Corporation for Major Vendor Expenses for the Sole Purpose of Receiving Volume Financial Rebates
	 
	 
The District is requesting authorization to utilize Third Party Pay processes with Bank of America, E-Pay and the American Express Corporation for major vendor expenses for the sole purpose of receiving volume financial rebates.  These services would allow the District to make payments to major contractors and vendors more securely and efficiently than the current method of paying by check.  It would also allow the District to hold cash longer; thus slightly increasing interest earnings while at the same time the contractors and vendors would receive payment earlier.  These agency provided services would be without cost to the District.  Not only would the services be at no cost but depending on the volume of dollar amount of payments made the District will receive financial rebates.  These rebates are currently estimated to be $250,000 of new income to the District.       
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$250,000 (estimated rebates)
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the authorization for the District to utilize Third Party Pay Processes with Bank of America, E-Pay and the American Express Corporation for Major Vendor Expenses for the Sole Purpose of Receiving Volume Financial Rebates.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of August 2010
	 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of August 2010, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting.”  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the warrant register for the month August 2010.

SUBJECT:
Approve Notices of Completion for Independence, Andrew Hill, W.C. Overfelt, Evergreen Valley, Santa Teresa and Foothill High Schools, New Solar Panel Posts Installation Projects
	 
Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on October 20, 2009, Chevron Energy Solutions has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to Independence, Andrew Hill, WC Overfelt, Evergreen Valley, Santa Teresa and Foothill High Schools, New Solar Panel Posts Installation Projects.
With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notices of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.
        
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$ 4,772,500 & $4,465,000 Total $9,237,500
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
School Facilities Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended the Board of Trustees approve the Notices of Completion for Independence, Andrew Hill, WC Overfelt, Evergreen Valley, Santa Teresa and Foothill High Schools, New Solar Panel Posts Installation Projects.
